questions.text: What should be the minimum percentage for normal sperm morphology in a seminal fluid analysis?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ WHO Manual for Human Semen Page 213

Parameters

Normal (Normozoospermia)

(WHO 2021 Guidelines)

Volume

> 1.4 ml

pH

7.2-8.0

Concentration

At least 16 million/ ml

Total count

39 million/ejaculate

Total Motility

42% or more

Progressive motility

30% or more

Morphology (most important)

4% or more

Pus cells (WBC)

1-2 million/ml

Viability

54% or more

questions.text: What can be done to address the concerns of a woman who is 3 months postpartum, regularly breastfeeding, and experiencing amenorrhea for the past 3 months, before considering surgery?
In a woman presenting with amenorrhea, headache, blurred vision, and galactorrhea, the appropriate investigation is:

A 16-year-old female patient visits the outpatient department (OPD) with a case of primary absence of menstrual periods and recurring pain. During the examination of the perineal area, a visible protrusion is observed from the vagina. Please identify the underlying cause for this particular presentation.

options.label: A
options.text: Transverse septum in the proximal vagina

questions.explanation:
Definition

Obstruction of menstrual blood outflow due to congenital malformations

Common Causes

Imperforate hymen, transverse vaginal septum, vaginal agenesis, cervical stenosis

Symptoms/

Complications

Primary amenorrhea, cyclic pelvic pain, abdominal mass, acute urinary retention, endometriosis, iatrogenic infections

Physical Examination

Bulging hymen, abdominal mass, possible tenderness on pelvic examination

Diagnostic Tests

Pelvic ultrasound (shows collection of blood), MRI (detailed anatomy), examination under anesthesia

Treatment

Surgical intervention to remove the obstruction (hymenectomy, resection of septum)

questions.text: Please identify the genetic disorder mentioned in the text.
What observation can be made from this hysterosalpingogram?
questions.explanation:
Preparation
  • NSAID 30 minutes before to prevent tubal spasm.
  • Paracervical block in patients with cervical stenosis.

4 phases of radiographic images taken
  • Pre-contrast preliminary.
  • During contrast filling.
  • Contrast spillage into peritoneum.
  • During deflation and withdrawal.

Contraindications
  • Acute pelvic infections.
  • Active uterine bleeding.
  • Allergic to iodine.
  • Pregnancy.

Doxycycline can be given
  • If dilated tubes are identified (indicating previous pelvic infection).
  • As prophylaxis to prevent infections post-HSG.

Complications
  • Pelvic discomfort.
  • Uterine perforation.
  • Vasovagal reactions.
  • Dye allergy.
  • Intravascular dissemination of the dye.

questions.text: A woman with a history of infertility is on treatment with human menopausal gonadotropin. She presented with the following findings in the given USG. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Category

Features

Mild OHSS
  • Abdominal bloating
  • Mild abdominal pain
  • Ovarian size usually <8 cm

Moderate OHSS
  • Moderate abdominal pain
  • Nausea ± vomiting
  • Ultrasound evidence of ascites
  • Ovarian size usually 8-12 cm
 
  • Clinical ascites (± hydrothorax)
  • Oliguria (<300 ml/day or <30 ml/h)
  • Hematocrit >0.45- Hyponatremia (sodium <135 mmol/l)
 
  • Hypo-osmolality (osmolality <282 mOsm/kg)
  • Hypoproteinemia (serum albumin <35 g/l)
  • Ovarian size usually >12 cm

Critical OHSS
  • Tense ascites/large hydrothorax
  • Hematocrit >0.55- White cell count >25000/ml
  • Oliguria/anuria
  • Thromboembolism
 
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome

questions.text: A 32-year-old married woman who came for the evaluation of infertility was found to have a septum in her uterine cavity. What would be the appropriate management of this case?
A 30-year-old female patient has a history of three miscarriages. Identify the investigation that was done using the image shown below.
questions.explanation:
Preparation
  • NSAID 30 minutes before to prevent tubal spasm.
  • Paracervical block in patients with cervical stenosis.

4 phases of radiographic images taken
  • Pre-contrast preliminary.
  • During contrast filling.
  • Contrast spillage into peritoneum.
  • During deflation and withdrawal.

Contraindications
  • Acute pelvic infections.
  • Active uterine bleeding.
  • Allergic to iodine.
  • Pregnancy.

Doxycycline can be given
  • If dilated tubes are identified (indicating previous pelvic infection).
  • As prophylaxis to prevent infections post-HSG.

Complications
  • Pelvic discomfort.
  • Uterine perforation.
  • Vasovagal reactions.
  • Dye allergy.
  • Intravascular dissemination of the dye.

questions.text: A couple presents to the infertility clinic with a normal hysterosalpingogram and a semen analysis report with azoospermia. Which of the following is the next best test to differentiate between an obstructive and a testicular cause of azoospermia?
questions.explanation:
1. Pre-testicular (central): endocrine disorders (low LH and FSH)
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism/ Kallman syndrome
  • Endocrine: Hyperprolactinemia, obesity, thyroid disorder
  • Drugs: Antihypertensives, Antipsychotics

2. Testicular (peripheral): Intrinsic disorders (High FSH and LH)
  • Genetic disorders:
    • Klinefelter syndrome (Most common)
    • Immotile cilia (Kartagener) syndrome
  • Varicocele: Most common reversible cause
  • Undescended testes
  • Testicular torsion
  • Mumps orchitis
  • Heat exposure: Miners
  • Toxins: smoking, radiation, drug abuse
  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia

3. Post-testicular: (Normal LH and FSH)
  • Congenital: Absent vas deferens (cystic fibrosis), Young’s syndrome
  • Obstruction: Epididymal and Ejaculatory duct obstruction
  • Acquired: Genital TB, gonorrhoea
  • Surgical: herniorrhaphy, vasectomy, bladder neck surgery
  • Other: Retrograde ejaculation, hypospadias

questions.text: The hysterosalpingogram of a patient shows fluid-filled S-shaped structures on both sides. Choose the best answer correlating to this finding.
During your internship, you notice the following instrument being used by the senior resident. The uses of this instrument include all the following except?

options.label: A
options.text: To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp

options.label: B
options.text: It is used to diagnose cervical stenosis

options.label: C
options.text: It is used in fallopian tube recanalization

options.label: D
options.text: It is used to measure the uterine cavity and the cervical length

questions.correct_answer: C. It is used in fallopian tube recanalization

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a woman who has a previous infertility history and is currently undergoing HMG treatment, based on the following findings in the USG?
questions.explanation:
Mathur Classification of OHSS

Mild OHSS:
  • Abdominal bloating
  • Mild abdominal pain
  • Ovarian size <8cm

Moderate OHSS:
  • Moderate abdominal pain
  • Nausea + vomiting
  • Ultrasound evidence of ascites
  • Increased Ovarian size (8-12 cm)

Severe OHSS:
  • Clinical ascites/hydrothorax
  • Oliguria (<500 ml/day)
  • Hematocrit >0.45
  • Hyponatremia (sodium <134 mmol/l)
  • Hypoosmolality (<282 mOsm/kg)
  • Hypoproteinemia (albumin <35 g/l)
  • Ovarian size >12 cm

Critical OHSS:
  • Tense ascites/large hydrothorax
  • Hematocrit >0.55
  • WBC >25000/ml
  • Oliguria/anuria
  • Thromboembolism
  • ARDS

Management of OHSS:

Management:
  • Avoid pregnancy in severe & critical forms
  • Remove fluids by tapping ascites & effusion
  • Oral fluids (Mild, moderate forms)
  • IV Fluids for replacement:
    • NaCl, DNS (crystalloids)
    • Albumin, Dextran, starch (colloids)

questions.text: A couple visited the outpatient department due to their inability to conceive. The husband's semen analysis came back as normal. The wife complained of excessive menstrual bleeding, and a hysterosalpingogram revealed the presence of distal tube dilatation resembling a "tobacco pouch appearance." What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
Which of the following patients would be classified as having primary amenorrhea?
questions.correct_answer: B. 14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts
questions.explanation:
Stage

Breast Development (Thelarche)

Pubic Hair Development (Pubarche)

Stage I

Prepubertal: No breast development

Prepubertal: No pubic hair

Stage II

Breast bud forms; areola enlarges

Sparse, straight, and slightly pigmented hair along labia

Stage III

Breast tissue and areola continue to enlarge

Darker, coarser, and curlier hair on the mons pubis

Stage IV

Areola and nipple form a secondary mound above the level of the breast

Hair becomes more adult-like, but does not extend to thighs

Stage V

Adult breast contour; areola returns to normal size, nipple projects

Adult distribution of pubic hair, extends to thighs

Stage

Genital Development

Pubic Hair Development

Stage I

Prepubertal: No genital development

Prepubertal: No pubic hair

Stage II

Enlargement of the scrotum and testes; skin of scrotum becomes reddened and thinner

Sparse, straight, and slightly pigmented hair at the base of the penis

Stage III

Increase in size of penis (length); further growth of testes and scrotum

Darker, coarser, and curlier hair, extending over pubis

Stage IV

Penis continues to enlarge (length and breadth); glans penis becomes more prominent

Pubic hair becomes adult-like, but does not extend to thighs

Stage V

Adult genitalia: Fully developed penis, testes, and scrotum

Adult distribution of pubic hair, extends to thighs

questions.text: Seminal vesicles and vas deferens would be bilaterally absent congenitally in which of the following conditions?

A 16-year-old presents with absent menses. Examination shows widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, and Tanner grade 1 breast development. USG shows streak ovaries. Investigation shows raised FSH, raised LH, and reduced estradiol. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Turner Syndrome

Kallmann Syndrome

 

(Option B)

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS)

(Option C)

Mayer-Rokitansky- Küster-Hauser (MRKH) Syndrome

(Option D)

Cause

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome (45,X or mosaicism)

GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) deficiency

Defect in the androgen receptor gene (X-linked)

Mullerian agenesis (absence of the Mullerian ducts)

Reproductive Organs

Streak ovaries (non-functioning)

Normal uterus and vagina

Normal ovaries and uterus

Testes present but undescended (cryptorchidism)

Absent uterus and vagina

Absent uterus

Normal ovaries

Breast Development

Usually absent or delayed

Usually absent or delayed

Normal or near-normal

Normal

Axillary/Pubic Hair

Usually normal

Usually absent or delayed

Minimal to absent

Normal

Karyotype

45,X or 45,X/46,XX

46,XX

46,XY

46,XX

Other Characteristics
  • Short stature
  • Webbed neck
  • Lymphedema
  • Heart defects
  • Learning disabilities
  • Delayed puberty
  • Infertility
  • Female external genitalia despite male chromosomes
  • Normal external genitalia
  • Primary amenorrhea

questions.text: A male patient presented for the evaluation of infertility. He has been having recurrent hospitalization for infections, since 2 years of age. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
Sperm count on a seminormal is 16 million/ml, with 40% motility and <1% of sperm with normal morphology. What is the term for this condition?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman who is being treated for infertility with human menopausal gonadotropin came with complaints of sudden abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness. USG reveals a classic spoke-wheel appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old woman accompanied by her mother-in-law came to the infertility clinic. She has been having regular intercourse for 6 months but is not able to conceive. What is the next step in the management?

options.label: B
options.text: Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

questions.correct_answer: B. Reassure and review the couple after 6 months
questions.explanation:
Evaluation of infertility based on aetiologies

Aetiology

Evaluation

Ovulatory function/ ovarian reserve
  • Ovulation predictor kit
  • Early follicular FSH +/- estradiol level
  • AMH level
  • Endocrine disorders (TSH, prolactin)
  • Ovarian sonography (antral follicle count)

Tubal /pelvic disease
  • Hysterosalpingography
  • Laparoscopy + chromotubation

Uterine factors
  • Hysterosalpingography
  • TVS /saline infusion sonography +/- MRI
  • Hysteroscopy +/- laparoscopy

Male factor
  • Semen analysis

questions.text: A 23-year-old female with 6 years of infertility has a BMI of 33 and facial hair. Investigations reveal she has PCOS and spills from bilateral tubes. She and her husband are trying to conceive. What would be the best management plan for this lady?

options.label: A
options.text: Metformin + Weight reduction + Ovulation induction with clomiphene

options.label: B
options.text: Weight reduction + Metformin +Ovulation induction with urinary gonadotropins

options.label: D
options.text: Weight loss + Folic acid, try for spontaneous induction. If failed, move to induction of ovulation

questions.correct_answer: D. Weight loss + Folic acid, try for spontaneous induction. If failed, move to induction of ovulation
